body.p:
June Term 1865
Commonwealth of Kentucky
against Marion Circuit Court
G W Graves Suffering Gaming
To His Excellency Gov Thos. E. Bramlett

The undersigned respectfully represents that he was at the June Term of the Marion Circuit Court tried and convicted of Suffering gaming upon his premises by permitting persons to play on a Pigeon Hole Table, and find the sum of $200 -- Now he says said fine in his humble opinion is excessive under the circumstances proven -- It was proven that he prohibited gambling on the said Table and stoped the game whenever betting was proposed That games were played on the table for who should pay for the treat such as whiskey cigars &c and upon this evidence his was convicted as aforesaid -- He had no idea that he was violating any law, nor no intention to do so -- and now asks your excellency to remit said fine beleiving that costs & expenses he will have to pay heavier punishment than the offense merits
Sworn to before me by G W Graves this 13th May 1865

N. T. Berry Examiner M. C.
over
The undersigned join in petitioning a remission of the fine herein before mentioned

B. Spalding
D Spalding
Ben Spalding Jr
J M Cardwell
James W. Fogle
B O Neel as one of the Jury
Francis Abell -- one of the Jury
James Elder one of the Jury
Beriah Glazebrook one of the Jury
The foregoing has been signed by all of the jury to whom the same has been presented, and I concur in the statements made by Graves as to the substance of the evidence against him

Marion Cir Ct
vs
G W Graves
Comth vs Graves
Pet for Remit
Marion Circuit
$200,
25 Oct 1865
